name: Tyrannosaurus rex
description: Perhaps the most famous predator of all time, this massive carnivore had a bite force capable of crushing solid bone. It ruled the valleys of North America with keen binocular vision and a terrifying roar.
funFacts: Its name means 'Tyrant Lizard King'.
T-Rex teeth were the size of bananas.
Despite their size, they may have been covered in simple feathers.

name: Velociraptor
description: A swift and intelligent hunter, the Velociraptor was much smaller than its movie counterparts but equally deadly. It used a large, sickle-shaped claw on each foot to pin down prey.
funFacts: They were roughly the size of a modern turkey.
Real Velociraptors were covered in feathers.
The famous 'fighting dinosaurs' fossil shows one locked in combat with a Protoceratops.

name: Triceratops
description: With its three signature horns and massive bony frill, Triceratops is one of the most recognizable herbivores. It used its formidable headgear to defend against predators like the T-Rex.
funFacts: Its head was one of the largest of any land animal, reaching 8 feet long.
It had a beak similar to a parrot's for snapping tough plants.
The frill may have been used for display and temperature regulation.

name: Spinosaurus
description: This semi-aquatic giant is easily identified by the massive sail on its back and its crocodile-like snout. It was likely the largest carnivorous dinosaur, even longer than the T-Rex.
funFacts: It is the only known dinosaur adapted for swimming.
Its sail was supported by spines up to 7 feet tall.
It hunted fish and ancient sharks in the river systems of North Africa.

name: Stegosaurus
description: Famous for the double row of kite-shaped plates along its back, this herbivore was a tank of the Jurassic period. It defended itself with a menacing tail tipped with four sharp spikes.
funFacts: Its brain was famously small, roughly the size of a walnut.
The tail spikes are informally called a 'thagomizer'.
The plates on its back may have blushed with blood to scare enemies.

name: Brachiosaurus
description: A true giant of the Jurassic, Brachiosaurus had longer front legs than back legs, giving it a giraffe-like stance. This posture allowed it to browse the high canopy that other dinosaurs couldn't reach.
funFacts: Its nostrils were located on the top of its head.
It could eat up to 880 pounds of plants every day.
Unlike many sauropods, it likely couldn't rear up on its hind legs.

name: Argentinosaurus
description: Widely considered one of the largest land animals to ever exist, this titanosaur shook the ground as it walked. Its sheer size was its best defense against predators.
funFacts: It may have weighed as much as 10 to 15 African elephants combined.
Its eggs were only about the size of a coconut.
It took 40 years for an Argentinosaurus to reach its full size.

name: Archaeopteryx
description: This creature is the famous 'missing link' between non-avian dinosaurs and modern birds. It possessed dinosaur features like teeth and a tail, but also had fully formed flight feathers.
funFacts: Its name means 'Ancient Wing'.
The first fossil feather was discovered in 1860.
It was roughly the size of a raven.

name: Iguanodon
description: Iguanodon was a bulky herbivore that could switch between walking on two legs or four. It is best known for the large, conical spike on its thumb, which it used for defense.
funFacts: It was one of the first three dinosaurs ever scientifically named.
Early paleontologists mistakenly placed its thumb spike on its nose.
They had advanced chewing teeth that could grind tough plants.

name: Allosaurus
description: Before the T-Rex appeared, Allosaurus was the apex predator of the Jurassic plains. It hunted in packs to take down massive long-necked dinosaurs.
funFacts: It could open its jaws extremely wide, like a snake.
It shed and replaced its teeth constantly.
A famous fossil specimen named 'Big Al' showed signs of 19 different injuries.

name: Acrocanthosaurus
description: Acrocanthosaurus was a large theropod known for the tall spines running along its back, which likely supported a sail or hump. It was a dominant predator in early Cretaceous North America.
funFacts: It used its strong arms to pull prey towards its body
Hunted large dinosaurs like the sauropod Paluxysaurus, leaving tooth marks on their bones.
Had large olfactory bulbs, indicating a good sense of smell, and its brain cavity suggests a downward-pointing head when resting.

name: Parasaurolophus
description: This duck-billed dinosaur is famous for the long, curved tube crest extending from the back of its skull. Scientists believe this crest was used like a trumpet to communicate over long distances.
funFacts: The crest was hollow and connected to its nasal passages.
It walked on four legs but ran on two.
Its skin had a pebble-like texture.

name: Giganotosaurus
description: A South American predator that rivaled and potentially exceeded the T-Rex in size. It specialized in hunting the colossal sauropods of its region.
funFacts: Its name means 'Giant Southern Lizard'.
It had a smaller brain relative to its body size compared to T-Rex.
Its teeth were serrated like steak knives for slicing flesh.

name: Ankylosaurus
description: The quintessential armored dinosaur, Ankylosaurus was covered in bony plates and wielded a heavy club at the end of its tail. It was the biological equivalent of a military tank.
funFacts: Even its eyelids had armored plates.
The tail club could swing with enough force to shatter bone.
It had a complex nose that may have heightened its sense of smell.

name: Carnotaurus
description: Known as the 'Meat-Eating Bull', this predator had two distinct horns above its eyes. It had incredibly powerful legs for sprinting but tiny, vestigial arms.
funFacts: Its arms were even smaller and more useless than T-Rex's.
Skin impressions show it had bumpy, scaly skin rather than feathers.
It likely specialized in high-speed pursuit of prey.

name: Protoceratops
description: A sheep-sized relative of Triceratops, Protoceratops lacked horns but possessed a wide frill. It is one of the most common dinosaur fossils found in the Gobi Desert.
funFacts: Ancient discovery of their skulls may have inspired the Griffin myth.
They lived in large herds and cared for their young.
A famous fossil captures one locked in a death grip with a Velociraptor.

name: Diplodocus
description: One of the longest land animals ever, Diplodocus had a tail that resembled a whip. Its tail was so long and thin that it could likely crack the sound barrier when swung.
funFacts: It could replace its teeth at a rate of one every 35 days.
Its tail contained over 80 vertebrae.
It stripped leaves off branches using peg-like teeth.

name: Baryonyx
description: This fish-eating theropod had a long snout and a massive curved claw on its thumb. It prowled the riverbanks of early Europe, scooping up slippery prey.
funFacts: Its name means 'Heavy Claw'.
Fossilized stomach contents revealed it ate both fish and Iguanodon.
It is a close relative of the Spinosaurus.

name: Gallimimus
description: Resembling a giant ostrich with a tail, Gallimimus was built for speed. It had a toothless beak and likely was an omnivore that ran from danger rather than fighting.
funFacts: It is one of the fastest dinosaurs, potentially reaching 50 mph.
It had large eyes located on the sides of its head for wide vision.
Its name means 'Chicken Mimic'.

name: Dilophosaurus
description: Recognizable by the twin crests on its head, Dilophosaurus was an agile predator of the early Jurassic. Unlike the movies, there is no evidence it had a neck frill or spat poison.
funFacts: The crests were fragile and likely used for display, not combat.
It had a notch in its upper jaw typical of early carnivorous dinosaurs.
It was much larger than its depiction in 'Jurassic Park'.

name: Oviraptor
description: Originally accused of being an egg thief, Oviraptor was later found to be a devoted parent brooding its own nests. It had a parrot-like beak and a distinct crest on its head.
funFacts: Its name unfairly translates to 'Egg Seizer'.
It was covered in feathers, resembling a strange flightless bird.
It had powerful jaw muscles for crushing hard food.

name: Compsognathus
description: Once considered the smallest dinosaur, Compsognathus was a nimble hunter of insects and lizards. It was the size of a chicken and darted around the tropical islands of prehistoric Europe.
funFacts: Its name means 'Elegant Jaw'.
It is one of the few dinosaurs found with fossilized prey inside its stomach.
It had two functional fingers on each hand.

name: Microraptor
description: This tiny dinosaur had four wingsâ€”feathers on both its arms and its legs. It lived in the trees of ancient China and glided from branch to branch.
funFacts: It is one of the smallest known non-avian dinosaurs.
Fossils show it had iridescent black feathers like a crow.
It ate small mammals, birds, and fish.

name: Muttaburrasaurus
description: Australia's most famous dinosaur, Muttaburrasaurus was a large herbivore with a distinctive hollow bump on its snout. It likely used this bump to create loud calls.
funFacts: It had teeth designed for shearing tough cycads.
It walked on two legs but could drop to four to feed.
It is the most complete dinosaur skeleton found in Australia.

name: Cryolophosaurus
description: Known as the 'Elvisaurus' due to the pompadour-like crest on its head, this predator ruled the cold forests of Antarctica. It proves that dinosaurs thrived even in polar regions.
funFacts: It is the first carnivorous dinosaur discovered in Antarctica.
The crest runs perpendicular to the skull, unlike other dinosaurs.
It lived when Antarctica was a temperate rainforest, not an ice sheet.

name: Therizinosaurus
description: One of the weirdest dinosaurs, Therizinosaurus had gigantic claws that grew up to three feet long. Despite these terrifying weapons, it was a pot-bellied herbivore.
funFacts: Its claws are the longest of any known animal.
It looked like a giant sloth crossed with a bird.
It used its claws to pull down tree branches, not to hunt.

name: Carcharodontosaurus
description: This 'Shark-Toothed Lizard' was a massive predator that competed with Spinosaurus in North Africa. Its serrated teeth were designed to slash through flesh, causing massive blood loss.
funFacts: Its skull was larger than that of a T-Rex.
It had 6-inch long serrated teeth.
It was a primitive cousin of the Giganotosaurus.

name: Giraffatitan
description: Often confused with Brachiosaurus, this African giant was even taller and more lightly built. It is the centerpiece of the famous Berlin museum display.
funFacts: Its name literally means 'Giant Giraffe'.
The crest on its head was once thought to be a snorkel.
It stood over 40 feet tall.

name: Sinosauropteryx
description: This small theropod was the first dinosaur fossil found that confirmed non-avian dinosaurs had feathers. It had a long, striped tail resembling a lemur's.
funFacts: Scientists determined it had ginger-colored feathers and a banded tail.
It lacked the complex wings of later bird-like dinosaurs.
It was only about a meter long.

name: Psittacosaurus
description: Known as the 'Parrot Lizard', this small herbivore had a distinct beak and cheek spikes. It is one of the most abundant dinosaur fossils, with hundreds of specimens found.
funFacts: Fossils show it had long, quill-like bristles on its tail.
It swallowed stones (gastroliths) to help grind up food.
It is an early relative of the Triceratops.

name: Patagotitan
description: A contender for the title of the largest animal ever, Patagotitan was a colossal titanosaur from Patagonia. Its thigh bone alone is taller than a human.
funFacts: It weighed an estimated 70 tons, equal to a space shuttle.
It was only discovered recently, in 2012.
A cast of its skeleton is displayed in the American Museum of Natural History.
